data.title: Swap position of editor toolbars?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot Editor 3.0 for all supported platforms

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964556/28320700-d848b706-6c03-11e7-94e7-e4fead222f18.png)

* To adapting to new layout changes is painful for who is using the old editor every day like me.
* In my opinion the toolbar contains `Run/Pause` buttons is used more frequently than the one contains `2D/3D` as we don't need to change the 2D/3D editor too much in real development.
* I think the time it takes to submit this issue is so short relative to change my habit to fit the new layout.

data.title: Status of C++ in Godot
data.body:
In Godot we are still using C++ 98/03. The aim of this issue is trying to decide whether we must still stick to it or either we can start using some modern C++ (C++11/14/17 and even 20) stuff.

When Godot was initially written, C++03 was the most current version and years later that style (version of the standard, avoidance of the standard library, etc.) was kept to avoid compatibility problems on certain compilers (some consoles, as far as I know). But we should recheck these concerns.

Items to consider (this list is intended to keep growing or having some entries discarded; just brainstorming at first):

- **Smart pointers:** Is Godot custom pointer/object mechanism compatible with that? Would Godot need to be rewritten in a big part to use them? Would the benefits be bigger than the cost?
- **Move semantics:** Questions to ask here are more or less the same as for smart pointers.
- **`auto`, `constexpr`, lambdas, etc.**: In general, any modern C++ feature that makes writing code easier and/or provides some chance of optimization without disrupting the current core.
- **Standard multiprocessing primitives**: C++ now provides standard threading, atomics, memory barriers, etc. Do we have to keep custom implementations and maintain them for different platforms?
- **STL/Boost/other**: Would we get some benefit by switching from custom containers to a good well-known implementation? Dis/advantages rergarding maintenance, performance, compatibility, etc.
- **`register`, inlining "tricks", etc.**: Stuff added to the code to try to make the compiler generate more performant code. Some of them either are deprecated or have no actual impact, or even can worsen performance. Which to drop? Which to keep?
- etc,

Small changes could be done early. But when should big changes (in its case) done? Godot 4.0? Or as soon as Godot 3.0 becomes stable?

Please let me invite some people explicitly: @reduz, @punto-, @akien-mga, @karroffel, @bojidar-bg, @BastiaanOlij, @Faless.

data.title: Adding back support for deprecated API methods to ease transition to Godot 3.0
data.body:
I know that change in scene files and API is necessary, but usually scripting system mantain old words for scripting compatibility. It´s ok that stetic-reasons recommend that get_pos() will be get_position(), but... Any reason for lost old expresion in scripting system?

This words change can fragment the valid gdscript code base-date in internet (people don´t actualize blogs, youtube tutorials, etc...). Is not posible to keep synonym expressions like "const" to new expression or something like that in the code base ( I don´t know c++ but something like:  get_pos() -> get_position() in GDScript module is possible?). By the fact with this changes there will be GDscript 1.0 and GDscript 2.0, add words look ok, but lost words?. There is debate in this topic?

data.title: KinematicBody2D with two collision shapes crashes on run
data.body:
_bugsquad edit:_ 
it seems it was observed on 79d85b7ff67e6edc700336ac112dad35e07fe102
Sample project is inside third comment.

-------------------------------------------------

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Kubuntu 17.04, Godot git master compiled today 

**Issue description:**
if a KinematicBody2D, with two collision shapes collides with a StaticBody2D with just one collision shape on it, crashes on run.  if you remove the second collision shape from KinematicBody2D it works just fine. if you add another collision shape to the StaticBody2D it works.

this I get on console: 
ERROR: operator[]: FATAL: Index p_index out of size (size()).
   At: core/vector.h:146.

data.title: "register" keyword
data.body: I was looking at new commits and found `register` keyword in e089989. This keyword is deprecated since C++11 and will be removed in C++17, so probably it's not needed there.

data.title: Improved math functions descriptions and added many AStar descriptions
data.body:
Edited/improved global descriptions (mostly from math):
`abs`, `acos`, `asin`, `atan`, `atan2`, `ceil`, `clamp`, `cos`, `cosh`, `exp`, `floor`, `fmod`, `is_inf`, `is_nan`, `round`, `sin`, `sinh`, `sqrt`, `tan`, `tanh`, `validate_json`, `weakref`, `INF` and `NAN`

From `AStar`, created all descriptions with except of:
`_compute_cost`, `_estimate_cost` and `get_available_point_id`

data.title: Cyclic dependencies aren't check when saving the scene, causing crashes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 – Godot master (bbada82)

**Issue description:**
If there's a cyclic dependency on instanced scenes, Godot detects and stops it from happening. But if you that before saving, the editor crashes when you save all scenes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
* Create two scenes (say A and B) and save them.
* Open both scenes inside the editor.
* Instance B inside A, and A inside B (without saving)
* Click on Scene > Save all Scenes
* Watch Godot crashing.

Funny that I tried this in stable, and the editor let's you do this without crashing... until you play the scene.

data.title: Dependency checking is not working
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 – Godot master (bbada82)

**Issue description:**
The checking of dependencies inside the editor is not working.

- The "Edit Dependencies" option in the FileSystem dock's RMB menu shows nothing, even when the file is a dependency. (Also, maybe this name is a bit confusing, as it should show what depends on the file, so "Edit Dependents" would be more accurate).
- Deleting a file from the FileSystem dock isn't warning if the file is used somewhere.
- The "Orphan Resource Explorer" is showing "0" to everything.

data.title: Fix Zlib license not extracted
AssetLlib should be able to filter plugins by compatibility with Godot version
data.body:
**Issue description:**
Since 3.0 is coming, we should have ability to filter plugins compatibility by engine version in AssetLib. We probably should display some kind of warning when user will decide to install plugin in non-matching version of the editor.
Also there should be a way for plugin creators to declare in which versions of the engine given plugin will work without problems.

![godot_2017-07-17_22-36-59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/28288742-7a1b6a8e-6b40-11e7-8d73-544e090a2298.png)

**Steps to reproduce:** Enable SSAO.

data.title: [3.0] Shaders: DISCARD can't be set from float / why is DISCARD a variable?
data.body:
In Godot 3.0 master, there is a DISCARD boolean variable available in fragment shaders. However, it can only be set to `true` or `false` explicitely, float conversion doesn't work, and using explicit cast `bool(step(x, y))` breaks the whole rendering with `GL_INVALID_OPERATION`.

Having DISCARD being a variable looks like the Cg way of doing things, where no `if` is needed (as far as I know, I take this from Unity shader examples).
However, in GLSL `discard` is a statement, and then requires an `if`.

Then, why is DISCARD a variable? Should it be converted to a `discard` statement?

Edit: actually, even using DISCARD correctly breaks rendering on my PC:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/28284579-c4c4535c-6b31-11e7-99c8-19feb4119d38.png)

Here is the top of the mesege:
```
ERROR: _display_error_with_code: SceneShaderGLES3: Fragment Program Compilation Failed:
0(1050) : error C1008: undefined variable "_discard"

   At: drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.cpp:167
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::get_current_version: SceneShaderGLES3: Fragment Program Compilation Failed:
0(1050) : error C1008: undefined variable "_discard"

   At: drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.cpp:459
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::get_current_version: Method/Function Failed, returning: 0
   At: drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.cpp:467
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::bind: Condition ' !version ' is true. returned: false
   At: drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.cpp:122
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::_get_uniform: Condition ' !version ' is true. returned: -1
   At: d:\projets\info\godot\engine\godot_fork\drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.h:376
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::_get_uniform: Condition ' !version ' is true. returned: -1
   At: d:\projets\info\godot\engine\godot_fork\drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.h:376
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::_get_uniform: Condition ' !version ' is true. returned: -1
   At: d:\projets\info\godot\engine\godot_fork\drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.h:376
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::_get_uniform: Condition ' !version ' is true. returned: -1
   At: d:\projets\info\godot\engine\godot_fork\drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.h:376
ERROR: ShaderGLES3::_get_uniform: Condition ' !version ' is true. returned: -1
   At: d:\projets\info\godot\engine\godot_fork\drivers\gles3\shader_gles3.h:376
mesege
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Error     ID: 1282        Severity: High  Message: GL_INVALID_OPERATION error generated. No active program.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_gles3.cpp:123
mesege
```

data.title: missing documentation for object.get_incoming_connections
Console error on changing Sprite.texture
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 17.04 296bd5739f74ee8433b3ecf3b03f389b14c2cc22

**Issue description:**
After changing Sprite.texture, the `Nonexistent signal: changed` error is printed in console. It comes from Object.cpp line 1514 (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/core/object.cpp#L1510)
![texture_change_console_error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/28281872-cfdff6a0-6b28-11e7-88c1-805b28ebf780.gif)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Add sprite to your scene.
2. Load some texture for it.
3. Load in runtime another texture with `$Sprite.texture = load("DifferentTextureFile.png")
4. Check the error console.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[TextureChangeIssue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1153523/TextureChangeIssue.zip)
